repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

body: I'm a little hesitant here.  We used to use the html5 regex, this was done in #1703.  But then we updated it to a new one, and I don't know where that regex comes from, in #2141.  Unless there's a good reason not to, I'd rather go back to the html5 regex.
We had this issue too, in Ukraine i.ua is quite popular email domain

Ok, so based on [this](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/pull/1894/files#r25748323) discussion, I think the first step we should take is to move to the html5 email validation regex, which can be found here:

http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/forms.html#e-mail-state-(type=email)

And see how that goes.  Looking at that, it looks like it supports one letter domain names.

In our tests we consider ".@mail.com" an invalid address because of the dot. As far as I can see the regex on w3.org which @jroper references does not take this into account. Our regex also considers "blabla..blabla@mail.com" an invalid address (double dots in the middle). Disassembling the regex is a pain, but comparing the two, I think that is the fundamental difference between the RFC and our implementation. Commit 6593f4e9e2407f0494355e5c2663b321c2e4820f allows for one letter domains without relinquishing our additions to the RFC. They are otherwise extremely similar.

The HTML5 regular expression is by no means comprehensive, but then, no regular expression for validating email addresses is.  At the end of the day, if you want to validate an email address, the only real way to do it is to send an email to it with a secret token.  For this reason, false positives are not a big problem, what is a big problem is false negatives, ie issues like this very bug.  By using a regular expression that's been developed very carefully as part of the HTML5 spec and is used all over the web as a defacto standard, we ensure with a high degree of certainty that we aren't don't have any false negatives.  In contrast, using a home grown regular expression like the one currently used opens us up to false negative issues like this one.

issue.title: Validate integer value in IntReads. Fixes #4032

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
The previous implementation would allow floating point values
to be parsed as integers. This commit validates the BigDecimal by
testing that the scale is smaller than 1. This would mean that the
number represented has no decimal points.

body: Very sound logic, that seems like the best approach. This would break some tests, I will fix this and create a separate pull request.

issue.title: Constraints.emailAddress regex error

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
if you attempt to validate an email address that contains a single char domain, Constraints.emailAddress incorrectly flags the address as invalid.

scala> Constraints.emailAddress("foo@x.com")
res5: play.api.data.validation.ValidationResult = Invalid(List(ValidationError(error.email,WrappedArray())))

issue.title: email validator fails for 1 character long hostnames

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
The email validator in fails to validate someone@x.org as a valid email address.

One character email addresses are not handled by the current regex which assumes a minimum of two characters for the host name.)

Examples: x.org, q.com

issue.title: Bug in email validation

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

body: The only comprehensive, RFC-compliant Java library I know of for email validation is Dominic Sayer's IsEmail: https://code.google.com/p/isemail/source/browse/Java/trunk/src/com/dominicsayers/isemail/IsEMail.java?r=65

issue.title: Email Validation

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
the current validtion for emails is done by this regex:
```"""^[a-zA-Z0-9\.!#$%&'*+/=?^_`{|}~-]+@[a-zA-Z0-9](?:[a-zA-Z0-9-]{0,61}[a-zA-Z0-9])?(?:\.[a-zA-Z0-9](?:[a-zA-Z0-9-]{0,61}[a-zA-Z0-9])?)*$""".r```
(line 80 in Validation.scala)
but this is not a correct validation for emails (my email for example is not allowed since it would contain an  (ue) which is technically allowed but blocked by this regex) it would be a good idea to just use the corresponding standart for mail adresses. For example java mail has an implementation of RFC822
